items.title: French police raid X offices as they investigate Elon Musk's social media platform and AI chatbot Grok
items.summary_auto: French prosecutors raided the Paris offices of social media platform X on Tuesday as part of a preliminary investigation into allegations that include spreading child sexual abuse images and deepfakes. They have also summoned X's billionaire owner Elon Musk for questioning.

items.title: Former B.C. lawyer found guilty of 1st-degree murder after killing his client in 2022
items.summary_auto: A former lawyer who admitted to killing his client in Kamloops in 2022 has been found guilty of first-degree murder by a B.C. Supreme Court judge.

items.title: Toys 'R' Us Canada files for creditor protection
items.summary_auto: Toys "R" Us Canada Ltd. says it has filed for creditor protection while it works to restructure the business.

items.title: Stephen Harper calls for Liberals, Conservatives to come together in the face of Trump, separatist threats
items.summary_auto: Former prime minister Stephen Harper urged the Liberal and Conservative parties to take on the challenges of our time together as the country stares down potentially two existential threats to its sovereignty: an imperialist president to the south and separatist movements in Alberta and Quebec.

items.title: Canada's next election likely to face AI-assisted interference, watchdogs say
items.summary_auto: Bad actors will likely use artificial intelligence and deep fake technology to try to disrupt Canada’s next federal election warn two of the country’s top election watchdogs.

items.title: CBC says it had 'no knowledge' of emails between Epstein and former employee
items.summary_auto: It appears that a former CBC Edmonton employee had multiple email exchanges with Jeffrey Epstein while he was in prison, the latest Epstein files drop reveals.

items.title: Heated Rivalry's Hudson Williams is writing a novel and loves Joan Didion
items.summary_auto: Hudson Williams, the Canadian star of Heated Rivalry, revealed in a recent interview with Wonderland that he is working on a "semi-autobiographical" novel and enjoys literary fiction writers.

items.title: Need help following the Olympics? Our newsletter has you covered
items.summary_auto: CBC Sports daily newsletter is in full Winter Games mode. Sign up now for daily updates including a viewing guide so you know exactly who, what and when to watch.

items.title: Premier says Alberta will withhold funding for judges without more input on selection
items.summary_auto: Premier Danielle Smith says her government will withhold funding to support new judicial appointments in Alberta if the federal government doesn't give the province more input on who is picked.

items.title: Here are the facts about Alberta separatism
items.summary_auto: Could Alberta actually leave Canada? The province could be headed to a referendum vote on the topic this year if a petition launched by separatists is successful. Here are the facts.

items.title: U.S. shoots down Iranian drone it claims 'aggressively approached' aircraft carrier
items.summary_auto: A U.S. navy fighter jet shot down an Iranian drone that was approaching the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln in the Arabian Sea, U.S. Central Command said Tuesday, threatening to ramp up tensions as the Trump administration warns of possible military action to get Iran to the negotiating table.

items.title: Hospital overcrowding key factor in long emergency room waits, Alberta study shows
items.summary_auto: Addressing hospital capacity problems is “critical” to reducing emergency room wait times, according to the authors of a new Alberta study.

items.title: Disney parks chief Josh D'Amaro replaces Bob Iger as CEO
items.summary_auto: Disney has named its parks chief Josh D'Amaro to succeed Bob Iger as the entertainment giant's top executive. The move comes as legacy studios stumble through a precarious time for Hollywood.

items.title: Inside Cortina's Olympic Village: A snowy haven for hundreds of athletes
items.summary_auto: Athletes at the Cortina Olympic and Paralympic Village on Tuesday chatted at an outdoor coffee stand, traded their unique national team pins and took in the atmosphere of the Dolomites as snow steadily fell.

items.title: How much $$$ will Milano-Cortina 2026 tickets cost you?
items.summary_auto: If you’re planning on attending a medal game for Olympic hockey at the Milano-Cortina Olympics there are still tickets available as of now. Just don't expect them to come cheap.

items.title: Canada rolls out whalesafe strategy to curb right whale entanglements
items.summary_auto: The federal government is rolling out its "whalesafe fishing gear strategy," a five-year plan to develop and support the use of new fishing gear to reduce the risk of entangling whales — specifically the endangered North Atlantic right whale.

items.title: Feisty Sam Bennett replaces injured Canada forward Anthony Cirelli on Olympic hockey roster
items.summary_auto:
Florida Panthers forward Sam Bennett has been named to Canada's men's hockey team for the Milan-Cortina Olympics in place
of injured Tampa Bay Lightning centre Anthony Cirelli.

items.title: Quebec man found dead with wife previously charged with assaults against her
items.summary_auto: The man found dead inside a Brossard, Que., home alongside his wife in an apparent murder-suicide had previously been accused of assaulting her with a knife and had agreed to wear an electronic tracking bracelet — but the charges were dropped.

items.title: Report urges Canadians to focus on health basics as 80% of premature heart disease and stroke preventable
items.summary_auto: More than six million people across Canada are living with heart disease or stroke, according to a new report with tips on what individuals can do to cut their risk.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Inside Milano-Cortina's Olympic Village
items.summary_auto: Media on Tuesday got to check out the Olympic Village — the temporary home for over 1,500 Olympic athletes, coaches and team members during the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Games.

items.title: 20 western Quebec doctors leaving because of controversial bill
items.summary_auto: Western Quebec's health authority says it is concerned that 15,000 people there are in the process of losing their family doctor. However, fewer doctors are leaving and fewer patients affected than previously thought.

items.title: Premier Eby says inconsistent communications between police sending wrong message to extortion victims
items.summary_auto: B.C. Premier David Eby says communication over the response to a wave of extortion crime, where suspects threaten residents or businesses with violence in exchange for money, has left people in Surrey confused over whether police are properly responding to the crimes and able to protect them.

items.title: Federal NDP torches Ontario NDP's Doly Begum for joining Carney's Liberals
items.summary_auto: Interim federal NDP Leader Don Davies is accusing Ontario NDP deputy leader Doly Begum of undermining democracy after announcing she will run federally as a Liberal for the seat vacated by former MP Bill Blair.

items.title: Red hats sweeping the U.S. as resistance knitters embrace 'melt the ICE' pattern
items.summary_auto: If the marching resistance to U.S. President Donald Trump's first term had a colour, it was probably pussy-hat pink. But knitted protest headwear has a new look in 2026, thanks to the popularity of a red "melt the ICE" hat pattern shared online by a yarn shop in the suburbs of Minneapolis.

items.title: Halifax police taking part in federal gun buyback program amid N.S. premier's opposition
items.summary_auto: Halifax’s municipal police chief says the force will participate in the federal government’s buyback program for banned guns, just a week after Nova Scotia’s premier said he believed the province would be “staying out” of the project.

items.title: What we know (so far) about the people accused in London, Ont., bomb-making scheme
She went missing in Canada in 1985. She may have been a Florida serial murder victim
items.summary_auto: Jeanette Marcotte was last seen in Saskatchewan in the early 1980s. Her remains were found in Florida in 1985, but officials didn't know her identity until a DNA firm, that helps solve cold cases, announced her identification last week.

items.title: U.S. ski star Lindsey Vonn confident she will compete in Olympics despite 'ruptured' ACL
items.summary_auto: Lindsey Vonn is "confident" she can compete at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics beginning this week despite the left knee injury she sustained in a crash four days ago.

items.title: NASA delays Artemis II launch due to hydrogen leak during rehearsal
items.summary_auto: NASA had been targeting a Feb. 8 launch date for the mission, which would send four astronauts including Canadian Jeremy Hansen on a 10-day journey around the moon. NASA says now March is the earliest possible window for launch, which will allow its teams time to review data and conduct a second rehearsal.

items.title: Judge rules against U.S. plan to strip 350,000 Haitians of legal status, notes 'racial animus' of Noem, Trump
items.summary_auto: A federal judge late  Monday blocked the end of protections that have allowed roughly 350,000 Haitians to live in the U.S., dealing President Donald Trump's immigration agenda another legal, though perhaps temporary, setback.

items.title: Australian boy, 13, swims for 4 hours to save family swept out to sea
items.summary_auto: A 13-year-old boy is credited with saving the lives of his mother and two younger siblings with an hourslong swim after the family was swept out to sea off the Australian coast.

items.title: BMO fined $4M by consumer watchdog for overcharging customers on discounted plans
items.summary_auto: The Financial Consumer Agency of Canada says it has applied a $4 million penalty on Bank of Montreal for overcharging customers after it failed to properly disclose fee details.

items.title: '2 tires, 2 flats': Montreal mayor shares her own pothole horror story
items.summary_auto: Montreal Mayor Soraya Martinez Ferrada got a firsthand taste of what it's like to drive on Montreal city streets Monday evening, when she hit two potholes on Notre-Dame Street and had to have her vehicle towed.

items.title: Iran's president seeks 'fair and equitable negotiations' with the U.S.
items.summary_auto: Iran's president said Tuesday he instructed the country's foreign minister to "pursue fair and equitable negotiations" with the United States, the first clear sign from Tehran it wants to try to negotiate as tensions remain high with Washington after the Mideast country's bloody crackdown on nationwide protests last month.

items.title: Clintons appear ready to testify in Congress about Jeffrey Epstein after contempt threat
items.summary_auto: Former U.S. president Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, will testify in a congressional investigation into the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a staffer said on Monday.

items.title: Rape trial begins in Oslo for son of Norway's crown princess
items.summary_auto: The trial of the son of Norway's crown princess, on charges that include rape, started on Tuesday, opening weeks of proceedings in a case that has cast a shadow on the royal family's image.

items.title: Partner of N.L. man who died waiting in hospital ER calling for inquiry
items.summary_auto: Robert Power, 69, died after a long wait for emergency care at the Carbonear General Hospital. His wife is calling for an inquiry into his death.

items.title: Partner of N.L. man who died waiting inside Carbonear hospital's ER calling for inquiry
items.summary_auto: Robert Power, 69, died after a long wait for emergency care at the Carbonear General Hospital. His wife is calling for an inquiry into his death.

items.title: Ontario's 'troubling' surge in unclaimed bodies is not letting up
items.summary_auto: The number of bodies that go unclaimed every year in Ontario continues to reach new record levels, according to the latest figures from the Office of the Chief Coroner.

items.title: Costco's beloved rotisserie chicken gets roasted in lawsuit over preservatives
items.summary_auto: In a time of skyrocketing food prices and turbulent economic times, Costco's rotisserie chickens are, for many, a reliable meal mainstay. But a new lawsuit filed in a California court has a bone to pick with how the retailer advertises its beloved cooked birds.

items.title: Why was Jeffrey Epstein allowed into Canada in 2014?
items.summary_auto: Nearly six years after pleading guilty to a crime that should have made him inadmissible, Jeffrey Epstein visited Canada, and federal government officials are providing no answers about why he was allowed into the country.

items.title: How a new, more sustainable lithium mining process could kick off the industry in Western Canada
items.summary_auto: As demand — and competition — for critical minerals used in clean technologies heats up around the world, mining startups are flocking to the heart of Canada’s oil and gas industry to tap into a key battery metal: lithium.

items.title: Gaps in menopause care push some Canadians to pay out of pocket
items.summary_auto: Some Canadians are paying for menopause care from a host of private practitioners opening clinics outside the public health-care system.
